abstract: Dorothea Lange’s photographs of Japanese-Americans interned during World War 2 capture not only the oppression of a people but also their struggle to retain their dignity.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Dorothea Lange’s photographs of Japanese-Americans, taken in the early 1940s, appear to show ordinary activities. People wait patiently in lines. Children play. A woman makes artificial flowers. Storefront signs proudly proclaim, “I am an American.”
snippet: Dorothea Lange’s photographs of Japanese-Americans interned during World War 2 capture not only the oppression of a people but also their struggle to retain their dignity....

headline.main: Rarely Seen Photos of Japanese Internment
